description: From Middle English denisein, from Old French denzein, from deinz (“within”) +‎ -ein, from Late Latin dē intus (“from within”), whence French dans.

entries.meaning: An inhabitant of a place; one who dwells in.
examples: The giant squid is one of many denizens of the deep.
The denizens of that pub are of the roughest sort.

entries.meaning: (Britain, historical) A person with rights between those of naturalized citizen and resident alien (roughly permanent resident), obtained through letters patent.
examples: Then by commaundement wer all Fre[n]chemen and Scottes imprisoned and the goodes seazed, and all suche as were denizens were commaunded to shewe their letters patentes  […]

entries.meaning: (biology) An animal or plant from a particular range or habitat.
examples: The bald eagle is a denizen of the northern part of the state.

entries.meaning: A foreign word that has become naturalised in another language.

verbs.description: denizen (third-person singular simple present denizens, present participle denizening, simple past and past participle denizened)

entries.meaning: (transitive, Britain, historical) To grant rights of citizenship to; to naturalize.
examples: He was denizened to Ireland after fleeing his home country.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To provide with denizens; to populate with adopted or naturalized occupants.
examples: There were a few islets in the sand  […] . These were at once denizened by the Calotropis, Argemone, Tamarix, Gnaphalium luteoalbum and two other species  […] .
